pullRequest.body:
Prove a weak version of the Bergelson intersectivity lemma. The proof gives the strong version, but we need natural density to state it. This is a prerequisite to Tao and Ziegler's recent paper [Infinite partial sumsets in the primes](https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10303).


---

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->
- [x] depends on: #14421
- [x] depends on: #14423 

See https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/18732

I think this PR looks good.
I think this PR looks good.
bors d+

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (hr : ∀ n, r ≤ μ (s n)) : ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion simp? ```
This is a false positive

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (hr : ∀ i, r ≤ μ (s i)) : ```
Am I correct that `strong_bergelson` and `weak_bergelson` only differs in the index? Perhaps you can call them `bergelson` and `bergelson'` for now.
Sure
This is the same as existing `ENNReal.div_self_le_one`.
Well it's similar, but it's not *the same*?
Should we use `Set.SurjOn` for the assumption?
It's annoying for import reasons
Turns out this is now possible at no cost

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion lemma preimage_subset_of_subset_image {t : Set β} (hf : Injective f) (h : SurjOn f s t) : ```
Is this no longer relevant? Which theorem fixes this TODO?
`measure_le_setLaverage_pos` and around
Could you please move it to an entry in the module docstring?
AFAIR, you've changed from explicit to implicit in some other cases. Does `(g := _)` work for you here?

This is different from the other cases you are thinking about in that `g` appears neither on the LHS or RHS, so it can only be unified for if we already have proofs of `hf_meas` and `h_bound`, which is impractical (especially if `f` and `g` are big).
